title: Vulnerability confirm endpoint does not have the confirmed_at and confirmed_by_id properties
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

When hitting the endpoint `/vulnerabilities/:id/confirm`, the vulnerability state is changed to confirmed and the vulnerability object is returned. However, unlike the similar endpoints `/vulnerabilities/:id/dismiss` and `/vulnerabilities/:id/resolve`, the `confirmed_at` and `confirmed_by_id` properties are not returned:

| Dismiss endpoint |
| - |
| ![DeepinScreenshot_select-area_20200331215131](/uploads/df5bd3614186e517effc30ec774094fa/DeepinScreenshot_select-area_20200331215131.png) |

| Resolve endpoint |
| - |
| ![DeepinScreenshot_select-area_20200331215156](/uploads/77bcd5e27c2e972225b55c6d21ca7ed0/DeepinScreenshot_select-area_20200331215156.png) |

| Confirm endpoint |
| - |
| ![DeepinScreenshot_select-area_20200331215321](/uploads/2b3a22e4c06308490e1a3f50d3e3ef28/DeepinScreenshot_select-area_20200331215321.png) |

This issue is causing the timestamp shown in the header to have the wrong time:

| Wrong time for confirm |
| - |
| ![Peek_2020-03-31_22-11](/uploads/43b15c2be3745a22709ba22227cf6be7/Peek_2020-03-31_22-11.gif) |

And if the user that last changed the status was different, the wrong user will be shown as well.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Follow the steps in this snippet to set up a local project that has vulnerabilities: https://gitlab.com/snippets/1956676
2. On the vulnerability show page, click on the dropdown on the upper right, click on "Confirm", then click on the "Change status" button:

| |
| - |
| ![DeepinScreenshot_select-area_20200331220207](/uploads/c609a0c6b803c07f6e2cf23f3bc4a6c1/DeepinScreenshot_select-area_20200331220207.png) |

NOTE: If the vulnerability status is already "Confirmed", the "Change status" button will be grayed out. In this case, select "Dismiss" or "Resolve", click on the "Change status" button, then you should be able to click on "Confirmed" and save it.

3. Verify using dev tools that the returned JSON data from the API is missing the `confirmed_at` and `confirmed_by_id` properties.

### Example Project

This vulnerability on staging can be used to reproduce the issue:

https://staging.gitlab.com/secure-team-test/security-reports/-/security/vulnerabilities/7774

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

Returned data does not have `confirmed_at` and `confirmed_by_id` properties.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Returned data should have the `confirmed_at` and `confirmed_by_id` properties.

title: Allow users to set confidential attribute on Epic
description:
User should be able to set confidential attribute when creating or updating an epic - we should update our private API (ee/app/controllers/groups/epics_controller.rb), REST API and GraphQL API to accept this attribute.

It should be allowed to set this attribute only if `confidential_epics` feature flag is enabled for epic's group.

### Frontend
On Epic List page, add Confidential checkbox to New Epic popover.

See design tab for latest mocks.

Related to https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/197339

title: Update Epic policy to take `confidential` attribute into account
description:
Epic's permissions should take into account also epic's confidentiality.
Because confidential epics will be implemented behind a feature flag, confidentiality should be checked only if `confidential_epics` feature flag is enabled.

Rules should be similar to [confidential issues](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/issues/confidential_issues.html#permissions-and-access-to-confidential-issues)

This task will update only Epic policy - there are some places where we check epic permission against epic group, but these will be fixed separately.

Related to https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/197339

title: Add `confidential` attribute to Epic model
description:
Similar to issues, user will be able to set an epic as confidential. We need to add `confidential` boolean attribute to Epic model for storing this setting.

There are additional restrictions for epic<->issue relationships:
* confidential epic can contain only confidential issues and sub-epics
* not-confidential issue can not be added to confidential epic
* not-confidential epic can not be set confidential if it contains confidential issues/sub-epics

Related to https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/197339

description:
https://sentry.gitlab.net/gitlab/gitlabcom/issues/1429748/?referrer=gitlab_plugin

title: Possible unnecessary field analysis in Elasticsearch
description:
I was just looking through the [field analysis](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/9558dd99c538a513dea0e41866f54da434ffaf3c/ee/lib/elastic/latest/config.rb) and wanted to note a few different fields that may not require any analysis. They could either be `keyword` or just removed entirely from the index which could save storage:

- `indexes :state, type: :text` => `keyword`
- `indexes :target_branch, type: :text` => `keyword` (maybe we want full text search on this but I don't know how valuable that is)
- `indexes :source_branch, type: :text` => `keyword` (maybe we want full text search on this but I don't know how valuable that is)
- `indexes :merge_status, type: :text` => `keyword`
- `commit.commiter/author`: `indexes :email, type: :text, index_options: 'docs'` => `keyword` (presumably we aren't really ever going to need to do full text search of author email of commits and there are many commits so this may save a good amount of space)

title: Guest users can't access the dedicated Release page
description: ### Summary In https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/34862, we fixed a bug that prevented Guest users from viewing a private project's **Releases** page. Unfortunately the fix (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/28447) uncovered another, similar problem: Guest users will get an error when clicking the title of a Release to view the "dedicated" Release page. ### Steps to reproduce - Create a new private project - Create a new Release in this project - Add a user to the project with Guest permissions - Log in as the Guest user and navigate to the project's **Releases** page - Click the title of a Release to navigate to the "dedicated" page for this Release ### What is the current *bug* behavior? The user gets a "Something went wrong while getting the release details" error message: ![Screen_Shot_2020-03-31_at_1.38.27_PM](/uploads/41173263d3b5484c10d361dffb9a2668/Screen_Shot_2020-03-31_at_1.38.27_PM.png) ### What is the expected *correct* behavior? Either: 1. The user does not get an error and the Release is rendered identically as it is on the main **Releases** page, or 1. The Release title is not rendered as a link on the main **Releases** page, so the user can not access the dedicated Release page. ### Output of checks This bug happens on GitLab.com. ### Root cause This is actually a much larger issue, because: 1. Releases are inextricably tied to Git tags; the tag name is used as the primary identifier for routing purposes 1. Guest users are not allowed to access any Git-related information in private projects, including tags For example, the URL to the dedicated Release page looks like `https://example.gitlab.com/user/project/-/releases/tag`. However, Guest users don't have access to tags, so they cannot access this URL. In fact, this is a small security issue: as shown in the screenshot above, we are leaking the tag name `test` through the breadcrumb to a user with Guest permission. This also has implications for features like ["search by Release"](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/search/#filtering-issue-and-merge-request-lists) and the milestone ["issue summary"](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/releases/index.html#releases-associated-with-milestones), all of which rely on URLs that include Git tag names. ### Solutions #### 0. Allow guest users to know tag names associated with releases From [this comment](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/213016#note_346621554). Currently, we have: ```ruby expose :name do |release, _| can_download_code? ? release.name : "Release-#{release.id}" end expose :tag, as: :tag_name, if: ->(_, _) { can_download_code? } ``` in the API, and ```ruby get ':id/releases/:tag_name', requirements: RELEASE_ENDPOINT_REQUIREMENTS do authorize_download_code! ``` on the dedicated release page api. If we just remove these conditions, we can allow users to visit the dedicated release pages without some of the content. Users still won't be able to: * download code * see commit hash * download evidence There are a few ways we can address this bug (and all other related issues): #### 1. Make tag information available to Guest users This would be the simplest solution, since it would allow Releases to behave more-or-less identically for Guest users as they do for Developers, Maintainers, etc. However, this _probably_ isn't an option, as this would be a change in security policy. But it might be worth investigating. #### 2. Always reference Releases by ID, not tag name If we used the Release ID as its primary identifier instead of its tag name, this issue would go away. For example, a Release with a URL like `https://example.gitlab.com/user/project/-/releases/v1.2` would instead be accessed with a URL like `https://example.gitlab.com/user/project/-/releases/2345`. This isn't as convenient or as nice to look at, but it would allow Guest users to interact with Releases without exposing the Release's associated tag. A change like this has the potential to involve a lot of development work. #### 3. Always reference Releases by some other unique identifier Exactly the same as number #2 above, except using a unique identifier other than the Rails ID. For example, we could add a first-class "version" concept and use this version as a primary identifier: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/213838 #### 4. Lock down Releases for Guest users A third option is to simply remove any feature that references tag names for Guest users. While this probably makes the most sense, it's unfortunate because almost _all_ features use tag names in some way, so the experience for Guest users will be very crippled. For example, Guest users: 1. won't be able to search issues or merge requests by Release 1. won't be able to click on issue or merge request counts in the "issue summary" section of Release blocks 1. won't have access to the "dedicated" Release page - For example, if a Developer sends a link to a "dedicated" Release page to a Guest, they will get a "404 - Page not found" error, which isn't intuitive since the Guest has access to the Release on the main **Releases** page

title: MR Comments and Changes not importing correctly during large Github project import
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

Many comments in Merge Requests in an imported project from Github fail to load with the `Something went wrong while fetching comments. Please try again.` banner. Additionally, clicking into the `Changes` tab displays: `Something went wrong on our end. Please try again!`

### Steps to reproduce

Import a project from Github with comments in a PR; view the matching MR after the import. Somewhat confusingly, some of the comments do come through possibly indicating some request frequency limit in Github being exceeded during the import.

### Example Project

https://gitlab.com/trackviaoperations/API-Node-SDK/-/merge_requests/3

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

When a large project is brought in, the comments on newer MR don't load.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

All comments in MRs are successfully imported.

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

Example MR highlight view:

![Screen_Shot_2020-03-31_at_11.58.03_AM](/uploads/d69bb99cffab1a7bdf0dc2fce079e855/Screen_Shot_2020-03-31_at_11.58.03_AM.png)

Clicking into the MR:

![Screen_Shot_2020-03-31_at_11.57.51_AM](/uploads/13e1073e75216332a059d07872465a06/Screen_Shot_2020-03-31_at_11.57.51_AM.png)

### Output of checks

This bug happens on GitLab.com

## Possible Workaround

Add all users to group before importing: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/213015#note_317501458

title: Instance-level Exportable Security Reports MVC
description:
### Problem to solve

Users are unable to effectively share the results of our security reports outside GitLab.  They need to provide these reports to their managers, compliance teams, and sometimes their clients. They need a human readable format that can be printed or sent via email.

### Intended users

* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)
* [Sidney (Systems Administrator)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sidney-systems-administrator)
* [Sam (Security Analyst)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sam-security-analyst)

### Proposal

***NOTE***: This should be built on top of the new standalone vulnerability object model.

For an MVC, we will add functionality enabling the user to download an Instance's security report in a CSV format. This includes:

* A button to download the report from the Instance-level Security Dashboard
* Dismissible popover calling attention to the new functionality containing a link to the [issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/197111) for leaving feedback (pointed to the button with a link to the feedback issue for first time view (does not reappear after dismissed))
* Generated CSV file is dynamically named such that it is easily recognizable and distinguishable from other reports.  For example: "instance-name_2020-01-01T14:05.csv"
* The contents of the CSV file will **only** include projects added to/displayed on the Instance-level dashboard.

**Suggested CSV Headers:**
This is not all data available in the [JSON security reports](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/sast/index.html#reports-json-format) (and not all of this data is in the security reports) but it should be the relevant information for such a downloadable report. First part is the suggested header field name, items in parentheses are the parameter name in the JSON schema from which to pull this data:

*  Group name
*  Project name
*  Scanner Type ("category”)
*  Scanner Name (“scanner”: {”name”})
*  Vulnerability ("name”)
*  Details (“description”)
*  Additional Info (“message”)
*  Severity (“severity”)
*  CVE (“cve”)
*  Status (not from JSON; this is vuln state like 'Confirmed', 'Dismissed', etc.)

### Testing

<!-- What risks does this change pose? How might it affect the quality of the product? What additional test coverage or changes to tests will be needed? Will it require cross-browser testing? See the test engineering process for further help: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/quality/test-engineering/ -->

TBD

### Documentation

Document the new functionality, being sure to clearly call out:
1.  This is for the Instance-level Security Dashboard
1.  Report is a CSV containing relevant data for ALL vulnerabilities present in default branch for all projects displayed on the Instance Security Dashboard; applying visual filters on the Instance Security Dashboard will not yet filter corresponding vulnerabilities from the report.
1.  Helpful screenshots, as appropriate

Suggested location: update to existing https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/security_dashboard/#instance-security-dashboard

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

<!-- Define both the success metrics and acceptance criteria. Note that success metrics indicate the desired business outcomes, while acceptance criteria indicate when the solution is working correctly. If there is no way to measure success, link to an issue that will implement a way to measure this. -->

We have at least one customer that can take our report export and use it to satisfy a request from an internal team or one of their clients.

### What is the type of buyer? 

~"GitLab Ultimate"

title: Group-level Exportable Security Reports MVC
description:
### Problem to solve

Users are unable to effectively share the results of our security reports outside GitLab.  They need to provide these reports to their managers, compliance teams, and sometimes their clients. They need a human readable format that can be printed or sent via email.

A related problem is the Group Dashboard current does not have a page title. This can lead to confusion about which of our many security-focused screens you are on as many look similar.

### Intended users

* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)
* [Sidney (Systems Administrator)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sidney-systems-administrator)
* [Sam (Security Analyst)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sam-security-analyst)

### Proposal

To address the lack of page title, this dashboard should now say "Group Security Dashboard" as shown in the mockups.

***NOTE***: This should be built on top of the new standalone vulnerability object model.

For an MVC, we will add functionality enabling the user to download a Group's security report in a CSV format. This includes:

* A button to download the report from the Group-level Security Dashboard
* Dismissible popover calling attention to the new functionality containing a link to the [issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/197111) for leaving feedback (pointed to the button with a link to the feedback issue for first time view (does not reappear after dismissed))
* Generated CSV file is dynamically named such that it is easily recognizable and distinguishable from other reports.  For example: "group-name_2020-01-01T14:05.csv"
* The contents of the CSV file contain vulnerabilities for all Projects in the selected group

**Suggested CSV Headers:**
This is not all data available in the [JSON security reports](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/sast/index.html#reports-json-format) (and not all of this data is in the security reports) but it should be the relevant information for such a downloadable report. First part is the suggested header field name, items in parentheses are the parameter name in the JSON schema from which to pull this data:

*  Project name
*  Scanner Type ("category”)
*  Scanner Name (“scanner”: {”name”})
*  Vulnerability ("name”)
*  Details (“description”)
*  Additional Info (“message”)
*  Severity (“severity”)
*  CVE (“cve”)
*  Status (not from JSON; this is vuln state like 'Confirmed', 'Dismissed', etc.)

### Testing

See the test engineering process for further help: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/quality/test-engineering/ -->

### Documentation

1.  This is currently for Group-level Security Dashboards only
1.  Report is a CSV containing relevant data for ALL vulnerabilities present in default branch for all projects in the group; applying visual filters on the Security Dashboard will not yet filter corresponding vulnerabilities from the report.
1.  Helpful screenshots, as appropriate

Suggested location: update to existing https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/security_dashboard/#group-security-dashboard

title: [FE] Add per-period deploy frequency to group level Value Stream Analytics
description:
### Summary

This issue represents the frontend implementation of the issue to [Add per-period deploy frequency to Value Stream Analytics (#210079)](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/210079).

### Proposal

Let's just use the existing metric card and:

* Add the `Daily deploys` as the left-most metric. This figure should be calculated as average deploys per day, and adjusted appropriately based on the timeframe selected in the UI (7/30/90 days).
* Re-name "Deploys" as "Deployment count" and move it to the left of "New issues" so it is the middle metric.

![Bildschirmfoto_2020-04-02_um_16.22.34](/uploads/3db4cae44c717788a3aad94b1fc1a8d0/Bildschirmfoto_2020-04-02_um_16.22.34.png)

See the backend issue for details on the API side: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/213004

title: [BE] Add per-period deploy frequency to Value Stream Analytics
description:
### Summary

This issue represents the backend implementation of the issue to [Add per-period deploy frequency to Value Stream Analytics (#210079)](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/210079).

### Proposal

The Value Stream Analytics backend should return a "deployment frequency" metric:

- "This figure should be calculated as average deploys per day, and adjusted appropriately based on the timeframe selected in the UI" ([source](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/210079#note_313651242)).
- It should be accompanied by a [`unit`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/210079#note_312948932) of "per day".

Some more fine points:
1. If the frequency is a decimal number, then we will display upto one decimal point

2. if hypothetically, a user selected a range of 1 day, we will return the total deployments of that day.

title: Policy to prevent login does not work as expected
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

As per the policy https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/policies/global_policy.rb#L47, blocked and internal users should not be able to login via the UI.
However, as a user of type `alert_bot`, I was able to log in via UI.

Please note that Blocked users work as expected - which I presume is possibly because of overriding `active_for_authentication?` for blocked users: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/models/user.rb#L302

### Steps to reproduce

1. Create an internal user
2. Try logging in as the user
3. Login works successfully

### Example Project

(If possible, please create an example project here on GitLab.com that exhibits the problematic behavior, and link to it here in the bug report)

(If you are using an older version of GitLab, this will also determine whether the bug is fixed in a more recent version)

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

Internal users are able to login via UI

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Internal users should not be able to login via UI

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

![bot_login](/uploads/78b422d3d7577954dd5807aa698a7d3f/bot_login.mp4)

### Possible fixes

Override `active_for_authentication?` method in user model to prevent blocked and internal users from logging in.

### Summary

In `WikisController#valid_encoding?`, we access `page.content.encoding`, but do not perform a `nil` check. This causes errors, such as:

https://sentry.gitlab.net/gitlab/gitlabcom/issues/1460527

### Steps to reproduce

See https://sentry.gitlab.net/gitlab/gitlabcom/issues/1460527 - some edit operations are loading pages with `nil` content.

### Output of checks

This bug happens on GitLab.com



### Possible fixes

Guard `@page.content` access.

title: Deleting release tags creates double activity entries
description:
### Summary Deleting a Release Tag from the **Tags** page creates a double entry in the activity log. ### Steps to reproduce - access a project with Tags - click the delete icon - view the activity for this user - there are 2 identical entries Problem also occurs if deleting from Release detail page ### Example Project - https://gitlab.com/sean_carroll/create-release-test-2 ### What is the current *bug* behavior? - creates 2 entries in activity log ### What is the expected *correct* behavior? - create a single entry in activity log ### Relevant logs and/or screenshots ![Screenshot_2020-03-31_at_11.46.52](/uploads/afd2e59a112dd727599c68c3d98418ec/Screenshot_2020-03-31_at_11.46.52.png) ![Screenshot_2020-03-31_at_11.48.42](/uploads/aa47d8f508c63092eef026bbcc610924/Screenshot_2020-03-31_at_11.48.42.png) ### Output of checks (If you are reporting a bug on GitLab.com, write: This bug happens on GitLab.com) #### Results of GitLab environment info
Expand for output related to GitLab environment info 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:env:info`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:env:info RAILS_ENV=production`)
#### Results of GitLab application Check
Expand for output related to the GitLab application check 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:check SANITIZE=true`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:check RAILS_ENV=production SANITIZE=true`)

(we will only investigate if the tests are passing)

title: Usage activity by stage create counters
description:

title: Store labels from jira issues as labels on gitlab issues
description:
In https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/209792 we simply added the labels assigned to issues on Jira to metadata section in GitLab issue description.

We should, however, create labels for GitLab issues appropriately. 

In case a label exists on the project, we should use that label. In case the label does not exist we should create a new one.

From https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/212651:

> Jira REST API has a dedicated endpoint to pull all the labels in a project https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/jira/platform/rest/v2/#api-rest-api-2-label-get we can use that to import all labels in batches, cache them and link the issues to the specific label. We have a dedicated stage for that as well `Gitlab::JiraImport::ImportLabelsWorker` `app/workers/gitlab/jira_import/stage/import_labels_worker.rb`

title: Use Kaniko to build images in GitLab CI
description:
Following up from https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/28225#note_314418693

As documented in https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/docker/using_kaniko.html, it is possible to use Kaniko to build and push images, without the downsides of DinD.

This also potentially gives the added advantage of being able to run the build jobs on forks, as the job can be executed on a non `docker` tagged runner.

The jobs that are directly using DinD image to build images are:
- all `gitlab:assets:compile *`
- `build-qa-image`

/cc @gl-quality/eng-prod

title: Update Container Scanning integration test to check all supported architectures
description:
## Summary

We need to update the Container Scanning integration test to check the following supported architectures, so as not to allow regression bugs like [this one](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/211873) in the future:

1. [x] Alpine
1. [x] Debian 
1. [x] Centos
1. [x] Red Hat Enterprise Linux
1. [x] Red Hat UBI
1. [x] Oracle Linux
1. [x] Amazon Linux
1. [x] Ubuntu
1. [x] openSUSE Leap (trivy only)
1. [-] SUSE Enterprise Linux (trivy only, no vulnerable images available)
1. [x] Photon OS (trivy only)
1. [x] Distroless

Rather than scanning one image after another, we can possibly scan all images at once, since [Change location fingerprint for Container Scanning
](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/215466) has been completed.


## Improvements

This change will help prevent regression issues in the future.

## Involved components
<!-- triage-serverless v3 PLEASE DO NOT REMOVE THIS SECTION -->
*This page may contain information related to upcoming products, features and functionality.
It is important to note that the information presented is for informational purposes only, so please do not rely on the information for purchasing or planning purposes.
Just like with all projects, the items mentioned on the page are subject to change or delay, and the development, release, and timing of any products, features, or functionality remain at the sole discretion of GitLab Inc.*
<!-- triage-serverless v3 PLEASE DO NOT REMOVE THIS SECTION -->

## Implementation plan

- [x] ~backend Add integration tests as `_spec.rb` files with corresponding Dockerfiles for each distro (first find proper image tag that contains vulnerability - looks for tags that are not likely to be updated),

Optionally (next step):

- [x] ~backend refactor specs and `.gitlab-ci.yml` file to accept list of distros that we want to test, then we will be able to quickly add support for new version without creating new spec files,
```yaml
.scanners-matrix:
  parallel:
    matrix:
      - SCANNER: [trivy, grype]
        DOCKERFILE_SOURCE: [Dockerfile, Dockerfile.ubi]
        INTEGRATION_TESTS:
          - debian:buster
          - alpine:3.12.0
          - proton:8.4
          - almalinux:8.2
          - amazonlinux:8.5
          - other-distro:111.111
```

Bower JavaScript air-gapped (offline) License Compliance
description:
### Problem to solve

Detect software licenses associated with dependencies declared using bower the same way we do today for online instances, in an offline instance relying on a proxied or locally hosted custom repository.

If possible this will deal with setting both address and optional authentication. If needed pop authentication into it's own issue.

### Intended users

* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)
* [Sidney (Systems Administrator)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sidney-systems-administrator)

Personas are described at https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/

### Further details

This change allows the retrieval of pip dependencies from non standard sources.

This is to support users in [offline GitLab self-hosted instances](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/offline_deployments/)

### Proposal


### Permissions and Security

same users today who can setup license scanning can set it up.

the repository may or may not be authenticated

### Documentation

We will need to update user documentation

### Availability & Testing

Manual: Use the existing GCP environment

Automated: Please work with ~Quality to make sure we have coverage as we must avoid regression

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

after following documentation it does not require an internet connection to run a scan and provide results.

### What is the type of buyer?

Heavily regulated industry, highly secretive organizations, and those with poor connectivity.

### Is this a cross-stage feature?

no


### Implementation Plan

* ~~[ ] Set up a custom bower registry in the Offline test environment. [bower/registry]~~(https://github.com/bower/registry)
* [x] Exclude [devDependencies](https://github.com/pivotal/LicenseFinder/blob/master/lib/license_finder/package_managers/bower.rb) from scan results. https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/license-management/-/merge_requests/150
* [x] Add integration test(s) to fetch dependencies from a custom bower registry. https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/license-management/-/merge_requests/150
* [x] Add integrations test(s) to verify that dependencies can be installed from a custom bower registry served with a custom self signed TLS certificate that is not in the default root certificate authority trust store. https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/license-management/-/merge_requests/150
* [x] Add documentation to describe any special setup or configuration required for fetching dependencies from a custom bower registry. [Example](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/compliance/license_compliance/index.html#using-private-maven-repos) https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/32706
* [x] Add documentation to describe any setup required for working in an offline environment. [Example](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/compliance/license_compliance/index.html#running-license-compliance-in-an-offline-environment) https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/32706
* [x] Add example project to [templates](https://gitlab-airgap-test.us-west1-b.c.group-secure-a89fe7.internal/templates) https://gitlab-airgap-test.us-west1-b.c.group-secure-a89fe7.internal/templates/js-bower

### Links / references

description:
### Problem to solve

Detect software licenses associated with dependencies declared using go the same way we do today for online instances, in an offline instance relying on a proxied or locally hosted custom repository.

If possible this will deal with setting both address and optional authentication. If needed pop authentication into it's own issue.

### Further details

This change allows the retrieval of pip dependencies from non standard sources.

This is to support users in [offline GitLab self-hosted instances](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/offline_deployments/)

title: Guest user can see tag names
description:
**[HackerOne report #833334](https://hackerone.com/reports/833334)** by `izzsec` on 2020-03-28, assigned to @rchan-gitlab:

[Security Implementation Issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security/gitlab/-/issues/317)

### Summary  
According to https://gitlab.com/help/user/permissions "Guest users can access GitLab Releasesfor downloading assets but are not allowed to download the source code nor see repository information like tags and commits.  
By querying releases api for a project that user has guest access to they are able to see tag names under the _links.self JSON field

### Steps to reproduce

1. Create new private project  
1. Add a guest user  
1. Go to Home --> Releases https://gitlab.com/<group>/<project>/-/releases  
1. Click New Release, enter any tagname and click create tag  
1. As guest user go to Releases the api page at https://gitlab.com/api/v4/projects/<project_id>/releases?per_page=20 will load   
1. Check the JSON response and see the tag name under _links.self  
1. Alternatively query the releases API with guest user token 

```  
curl -X GET -H "Private-Token: <PRIVATE_TOKEN>" https://gitlab.com/api/v4/projects/<project_id>/releases  
```

JSON snippet with _links.self and tag name  
```  
"_links": {  
      "self": "https://gitlab.com/<group>/<project>/-/releases/<tag_name>"  
    }  
```

### Impact  
Guest users can see tag names

### Examples  
This happens on gitlab.com. 

### What is the current *bug* behavior?  
Guest users can see tag names

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?  
Tag names should not be displayed to guest users.

## Impact

Guest users can see tag names

title: Clean up dependency_list_ui feature flag and old code paths
description:
#195928 changes the Dependency List UI. Those changes are implemented behind the `dependency_list_ui` feature flag.

Once #195928 has been completed, the feature flag and old code paths/components should be cleaned up.

This includes (but is not limited to):

* Removing completely
    *  [ee/app/assets/javascripts/dependencies/components/dependencies_table_row.vue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/v12.9.1-ee/ee/app/assets/javascripts/dependencies/components/dependencies_table_row.vue) and tests
* Deleting old code paths where the feature flag is disabled
    * [ee/app/assets/javascripts/dependencies/components/app.vue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/v12.9.1-ee/ee/app/assets/javascripts/dependencies/components/app.vue)
    * [ee/app/assets/javascripts/dependencies/components/dependencies_table.vue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/v12.9.1-ee/ee/app/assets/javascripts/dependencies/components/dependencies_table.vue)
* Refactoring the Vuex store, to remove some complexity introduced by having two tabs in the previous UI.
